comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: Frances B. Roeder was an American soprano. She was the subject a few items published in the New York Times during the 1910s. She was the daughter of Augustus "Gus" Roeder of Brooklyn, a staff member of The New York World. An item published in The Times on May 18, 1913, mentioned that she was scheduled to make her debut at Covent Garden, London, as Musetta, in a production of La Boheme featuring Nellie Melba and John McCormack in the leads. But an article in the December 28, 1913 Times, when she was scheduled to sing at Nice, France, said that she had only appeared in "small parts" at Covent Garden the previous spring. Her career doesn't seem to have gone anywhere after that. By 1917, she was listed among the members of the large cast of a musical review called Cheer Up, at the Hippodrome Theatre in New York. In 1919 she married a Mr. George Chorpenning of New York, among the wedding announcements in the June 26 New York Times. After that, I find nothing about her in the archives.
